lessons.name: Red-Crowned Parrot
lessons.content: In 2011, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service announced that the red-crowned parrot warranted federal protection. They too acknowledged that the birds' homes have been lost, and that they've been poached for the pet trade. They want the birds to be protected by being on America's official list of endangered species.

lessons.name: Eclipse of 2017
lessons.content: During the eclipse of 2017, the Moon's shadow raced over the Earth's surface at more than 2,000 miles per hour. A roughly 65-mile-wide zone, called the path of totality, offered the best viewing. Stars and planets came out, and the Sun's corona glowed in a perfect circle around the dark side of the Moon.

lessons.name: Thomas Jefferson
lessons.content: Thomas Jefferson, the third of ten children, was born on April 13, 1743 in Shadwell, Virginia into a planter family. His parents were Peter and Jane Jefferson. He had six sisters and three brothers. At 9 years old Jefferson began studying Latin, Greek, and French; he also learned to ride horses, and began to study nature.

lessons.name: Food Allergies
lessons.content: Food allergies are fairly common amongst adults and even more so among children. Around 2% of adults and 8% of children suffer from some type of food allergy where the immune system makes a mistake and thinks a certain food protein is dangerous and attacks it. Common food allergies are to seafood and peanuts.

lessons.name: Stewardess
lessons.content: "Stewardesses" is the longest word that is typed with only the left hand. A stewardess is a woman who is employed to provide meals for and otherwise look after passengers on a ship or aircraft. These days, we typically use the term flight attendant, which can refer to a man or woman that performs this job. What other words are typed with only one hand?

lessons.name: Indiana
lessons.content: Indiana is a state in the United States. Its capital and largest city is Indianapolis. Other famous cities and towns include Bloomington, Gary, Ft. Wayne, South Bend, Evansville, Muncie, and Marion. People who live in Indiana or are from there are called Hoosiers. Indiana's state bird is a Cardinal, Indiana's state flower is a Peony, Indiana's state tree is a Tulip Tree.

lessons.name: Smart Phones
lessons.content: Nowadays, phones are clever enough to grasp your physical surroundings. They can detect the size of a room and the presence of other people. Kids studying the Mesozoic Era would be able to place a virtual Tyrannosaurus in their home or classroom. The technology would even know when to display information about a scene depicted in a painting as you stroll through a museum.
